docs.abstract: All of the Oscar winners can be watched at home. Here’s a guide.
docs.snippet: All of the Oscar winners can be watched at home. Here’s a guide.
docs.lead_paragraph: Every single Oscar winner is available for home viewers to watch right now, including “Nomadland,” which won major prizes for best picture, best director and best actress, and has been streaming on Hulu for months. The big questions are where, how and how much: Some are exclusive to popular streaming services like Netflix, some are affordable rentals while a couple more recent releases are $19.99, and some can be streamed and bought but not rented while others can be rented but not bought. Sound confusing? The list of Oscar winners below will put you a click away from knowing all the options and discovering whether or not the Academy got it right.

headline.main: Where to Stream ‘Nomadland’ and Other Big Oscar Winners

docs.abstract: The testimony was partly an effort by the prosecution to show that Mr. Floyd had a high tolerance for fentanyl, which could undercut any argument that he died of a drug overdose.
docs.snippet: The testimony was partly an effort by the prosecution to show that Mr. Floyd had a high tolerance for fentanyl, which could undercut any argument that he died of a drug overdose.
docs.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — They met one evening four summers ago, and she was instantly drawn to his “great, deep, Southern voice.” She gave him her phone number that night, and they became close, exploring the city’s sculpture garden and its vibrant restaurant scene. Soon she was simply calling him “Floyd,” just like his friends did.

headline.main: George Floyd’s Girlfriend Says Opioid Addiction Was a Struggle They Shared
headline.print_headline: Floyd’s Girlfriend Recounts Shared Struggle With Addiction

byline.original: By Tim Arango, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Julie Bosman

docs.abstract: Davis said: “If I offended the family, then I’m deeply, deeply disappointed.”
docs.snippet: Davis said: “If I offended the family, then I’m deeply, deeply disappointed.”
docs.lead_paragraph: The reverberations throughout the sports world came swiftly after a jury in Minnesota convicted Derek Chauvin on Tuesday of murdering George Floyd, as athletes, teams and leagues weighed in on the verdict in a case that had reignited fierce debate about racism and policing in the United States.

headline.main: Sports world celebrates Chauvin verdict amid controversy over Raiders’ ‘I can breathe’ tweet.

docs.abstract: She was known as Juror 96 and sat through three weeks of testimony, but Lisa Christensen didn’t get to decide Derek Chauvin’s fate. She was selected as an alternate.
docs.snippet: She was known as Juror 96 and sat through three weeks of testimony, but Lisa Christensen didn’t get to decide Derek Chauvin’s fate. She was selected as an alternate.
docs.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Lisa Christensen stood feet from the blue angel painted on a patch of pavement she had become intimately familiar with over the past month. Under the spittle of rain droplets, she clasped her hands in front of her chest and said a prayer to George Floyd.

headline.main: ‘I Could Feel Their Pain’: A Juror on the Chauvin Trial Speaks Out
headline.print_headline: Alternate Juror on Chauvin Trial Speaks Out: ‘I Could Feel Their Pain’

docs.abstract: Times photographers captured the events across Minneapolis as the trial over the death of George Floyd began.
docs.snippet: Times photographers captured the events across Minneapolis as the trial over the death of George Floyd began.
docs.lead_paragraph: Minneapolis was a city of protest and remembrance during the first days of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the white former police officer who is on trial in the death of George Floyd, the Black man whose neck he knelt on for more than nine minutes during an arrest last May.

headline.main: On the Scene: Week 1 of the Trial of Derek Chauvin
headline.print_headline: Scenes From a City Holding Its Breath, Waiting for Justice

docs.abstract: A dictionary for these polarized times.
docs.snippet: A dictionary for these polarized times.
docs.lead_paragraph: President Biden campaigned on a promise to unify America. An inspiring goal, to be sure, but one that ain’t anywhere close to happening. Decades of polarization, turbocharged by the us-versus-them philosophy of former President Donald Trump, have left the nation so divided that it can feel as though the two political teams are not only talking past each other but speaking in entirely different tongues.

headline.main: Democrats and Republicans No Longer Speak the Same Language
headline.print_headline: A Dictionary for Our Polarized Times

docs.abstract: West St. Paul, Minn., says the nearly 75-foot message violates multiple portions of city code. The conflict is brewing as the Twin Cities region uneasily awaits a verdict in the Derek Chauvin trial.
docs.snippet: West St. Paul, Minn., says the nearly 75-foot message violates multiple portions of city code. The conflict is brewing as the Twin Cities region uneasily awaits a verdict in the Derek Chauvin trial.
docs.lead_paragraph: The colorful mural, adorned with hearts, a portrait of a local activist and the words “Black Lives Matter,” stands out at a busy intersection in West St. Paul, a community nestled against the Twin Cities. It is a cherished symbol for many Black residents, a site of reflection and pride.

headline.main: His Fence Says ‘Black Lives Matter.’ His City Says Paint Over It.
headline.print_headline: A 75-Foot Fence Affirms That Black Lives Matter. A City Says It Has to Go.

byline.original: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio

docs.abstract: States have passed over 140 police oversight bills since the killing of George Floyd, increasing accountability and overhauling rules on the use of force. But the calls for change continue.
docs.snippet: States have passed over 140 police oversight bills since the killing of George Floyd, increasing accountability and overhauling rules on the use of force. But the calls for change continue.
docs.lead_paragraph: In February, Illinois enacted a law that rewrote many of the state’s rules of policing, and mandated that officers wear body cameras. In March, New York City moved to make it easier for citizens to sue officers. This month, the Maryland legislature — which decades ago became the first to adopt a Law Enforcement Officers’ Bill of Rights — became the first to do away with it.

headline.main: As New Police Reform Laws Sweep Across the U.S., Some Ask: Are They Enough?
headline.print_headline: New Police Reform Laws Seize on Calls for Change

byline.original: By Steve Eder, Michael H. Keller and Blacki Migliozzi

docs.abstract: The Justice Department has opened up a new avenue for potentially major policy shifts in the city.
docs.snippet: The Justice Department has opened up a new avenue for potentially major policy shifts in the city.
docs.lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin had worked for almost two decades at the Minneapolis Police Department, amassing a history riddled with accusations of abuse, before he murdered George Floyd on May 25, 2020.

headline.main: What Might Bring Changes to Policing in Minneapolis?

docs.abstract: The corporate response to civil rights has changed over the years.
docs.snippet: The corporate response to civil rights has changed over the years.
docs.lead_paragraph: Andrew here. Yesterday’s guilty verdict against George Floyd’s murderer, a former Minneapolis police officer, was a symbol of something profound: a demonstrable shift in the way this country, increasingly supported by business, has strived for civil rights.

headline.main: More Businesses Are Standing for Justice

byline.original: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
